column1:
18:52|eight minutes to seven|As they passed the common a quick glance at the clock in the Town Hall gave them the time. It was just eight minutes to seven.
“You’ll be cold
column3:
as he noted that Willard had no overcoat on.
“No
column4: I won’t; not very. There wasn’t time to find anything.” Willard dropped his voice. “How badly is he hurt

column1: 18:52|eight— minutes to seven|We've missed the train! It's ten —eight— minutes to seven
column3: in a voice which combined reproach and terror. And he sprang out of bed and began with hysteric fury to sort out his garments.|Catching the Train|Arnold Bennett

column1: 18:52|near on seven o'clock|It was near on seven o'clock when I got to Mr. and Mrs. Fleming's house on 6th Street
column2: where I was renting a room. It was late September
column3: and though there was some sun left
column4: I didn't want to visit a dead man's place with night coming on.|All Aunt Hagar's Children|Edward P. Jones
